Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Surrogate System Hypothesis for Joint Mechanics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is aimed at understanding the fundamental physics governing the behavior of mechanical joints in engineered structures. Mechanical joints are essential and integral parts of engineered systems and yet the physics governing them is largely unknown. This lack of knowledge prevents engineers and designers from developing predictive models of a jointed structure that can be used to guide its design. As a result, jointed structures are often overdesigned to prevent failure from occurring. In low consequence applications, such as an office chair, home electronic appliance, etc., overdesign of the jointed interface has little practical consequence. For high consequence applications, such as aero-turbines for passenger jets, the fuselage of rockets, defense applications, or the frame of an automobile, overdesign can have significant ramifications in terms of fuel efficiency and safety. If a predictive model of jointed structures existed (i.e. one that predicts both the stiffness of a joint and how much energy it dissipates), then joints could be properly designed contributing their appropriate weight to the structure, with the potential of reducing fuel consumption. A second outcome is that the predictive model could be used in design of jointed interfaces to dissipate energies that might otherwise damage other components of the assembly, such as sensitive electronics within a rocket. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project seeks to address this gap in predictive capability by developing a rigorous framework, the surrogate system hypothesis, in which a jointed interface can be characterized out of context (avoiding complications associated with high manufacturing expenses for the real system or multiple sources of contamination in measurements such as from other joints within the system) and then used to predict the response of the joint within the system of interest with high accuracy.

The surrogate system hypothesis states that a surrogate structure that contains the same joint as the system of interest can be used to deduce the properties of the joint. These properties, once accounting for the properties of the surrogate structure, can then be substituted directly into the system of interest as a spatially discrete joint model (as opposed to a modal model). The goal of this project is to test the surrogate system hypothesis to determine if, under varied loading conditions and in realistic structures, it is supported by experimental evidence. The experimental investigations must, by nature of the hypothesis, be in combination with numerical modeling efforts, which will be built upon recently matured reduced order modeling techniques from the dynamic substructuring community for studying the response of a jointed structure. The work is divided into several objectives: testing the surrogate system hypothesis in new regimes in order to challenge its underlying assumptions, determining the bounds of the hypothesis' limitations, and demonstrating proof-of-concept on a realistic system with more complex geometries. If the surrogate system hypothesis finds support, it will enable several significant advances for contact mechanics in addition to the design and optimization of assemblies. This research will enable a new approach for predictive models of joints based off of well-characterized surrogate systems. Once a predictive approach is developed, it will be possible to detect potential failures at the design phase before hardware is manufactured. The ramification of this research is that, if successful, this hypothesis indicates that micro- and nano-scale effects, such as the distribution of asperities, are secondary to determining the dynamics of a structure behind the macro-scale features such as geometry and mean roughness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated a novel approach for modeling the dynamics of assembled structures (i.e. any structure fabricated by joining together, whether by bolts, welds, etc, two or more parts). The challenge behind modeling assembled structures is that the physics internal to a jointed interface is not well understood. For instance, while Coulomb's model of f = μN is generally accepted for describing friction at a macroscopic view, it does not work for modeling the friction internal to a joint. For structures that are of low consequence (such as a chair), a highly accurate, predictive model is not necessary as conservancy in the design of the structure can be used to overcome the lack of knowledge about interfaces. For high consequence structures (such as aerospace applications), over designing a structure can have significant negative ramifications (such as costing an airline billions of dollars of fuel per year more than necessary). Thus, more accurate modeling approaches are needed to design assemblies used for high consequence applications.

Building on recent observations, the surrogate system hypothesis stipulates that a joint can be modeled using the measured properties of a geometrically identical joint in a surrogate structure, which is designed to be easier to manufacture, to contain only a single source of nonlinearity, and to span a larger response range than the joint in the original structure. This approach enables a modular approach to modeling jointed structures - characterize a specific type of joint, then use the resulting numerical model throughout the entire assembly of interest.

In this research, the surrogate system hypothesis found strong support in the experimental and numerical work conducted. Further, it was found that support for the hypothesis was independent of the friction model used to construct a representative joint model. The ramifications of this finding are two-fold. First, accurate representations of a joint's behavior in a novel structure can be successfully predicted without improved models of interfacial friction; and second, the limitations of previous modeling approaches were due to a lack of understanding of how to relate the dynamic loading of a frictional interface to the model of the joint.

In order to have a better understanding of how the dynamic loading of a frictional interface are related to the model of a joint, these results initiated a new branch of inquiry: how do the tribology, contact mechanics, and dynamics of a joint combine to determine the dynamics of an assembly? This new branch of inquiry, termed tribomechadynamics, is a multi-scale approach to analyzing structures with frictional interfaces. At the core of this research initiative are a series of experimental observations that invalidate many of the previously held assumptions regarding the modeling of jointed structures:

-        The contact pressure within an interface is constant

-        The interface is stuck together under the frustra of the bolts

-        There are no significant local dynamics within the interface

-        Energy dissipation in the interface is due to microslip

-        Higher bolt torques lead to larger contact areas

-        The interface exhibits symmetric behavior

-        No macroslip occurs at nominal loads

Each of these assumptions, in addition to several others, were demonstrated to be invalid for jointed structures through a series of measurements using high speed videography and electronic pressure films to measure the local kinematics of the interface and the evolving pressure field within the interface itself.

One additional outcome of the experimental studies is the observation that the microstructure of an interface is integral for understanding the dynamics of a jointed structure. Surface features on the order of 10 μm can significantly change the natural frequency of a structure that is meters in size (upwards of 10%!). Once these surface features are incorporated into a modeling framework that is compatible with the other experimental observations, it was demonstrated that it is possible to blindly predict the dynamics of a jointed structure. Previous attempts at this resulted in errors in frequency of up to 25% and errors in dissipative capacity of up to two orders of magnitude. By contrast, using the same friction models, the measured errors for the tribomechadynamic modeling approach are on the order of 0.2% for frequency and 2% for dissipative capacity.

Coupled with new numerical solvers to enable efficient simulations of jointed structures, this new tribomechadynamic modeling framework enables researchers to perform predictive design optimizations of jointed structures. It is estimated that this will have a potential net impact of trillions of dollars on the global economy through the reduction of fuel consumption, the reduction of qualification tests needed to calibrate and validate models, and through design optimization to enable higher performance of machines.
